editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Hannah Bredar

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: The witty fair one. A comedy.
As it was presented at the private house in Drury lane. By her majesty's servants.

quote.l: Men 'Moveat cimex pantiluis? aut crucier, quod

div.p: London printed by B. A. and T. F. for Wil. Cooke, and are to be sold at his shop, near Furnivals-inn gate, in Holborn. 1633.

div.head: To the truly noble knight sir Edward bushel.
div.p: Sir, your candid censure of some unworthy poems which I have presented to the world, long since made me your servant in my thoughts, and being unwilling to rest long in the silent contemplation of your nobleness, I presumed at last to send this comedy, to kiss your hand, as the first degree to my greater happiness in your more particular knowledge of me; it wanted no grace on the stage, if it appear acceptable to you in this new trim of the press, it will improve abroad, and you oblige the author to acknowledge a favour beyond the first applause. Pardon the rudeness of my public address to you, in the number of many whom which more excuse, I might have interrupted. I am bold, but your mercy will incline you not to despise these (At the worst) but errors of my devotion, and the weak expression of his service, whose desires are to be known,

list.item: Sir George, an old rich knight.
Mr. fowler, a wild young gentleman.
Tutor, and companion to sir Nicholas.

div.head: Scaena, i.
div.stage: Enter sir George Richley, master worthy, whibble a servant.

sp.speaker: Mr. worthy.
sp.p: So soon after dinner?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo:
sp.p: I am engaged, and must away, excuse me brother.

sp.speaker: M. Wor:
sp.p: Well, make ready his horse.

sp.speaker: Whib.
sp.p: His worship's pad shall be prepared: if your Golding be not ready in a minute, your worship shall ride me.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo:
sp.l: I shall not need to urge your care upon
My daughter, on whom next the devotion of
My soul to heaven, all my desires
And thoughts reflect, I leave her to your trust,
And in my absence doubt not you will be
Both uncle and a father.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Willingly, I would depose myself from both those titles,
To serve my niece, her virtue will reward me,
I know she is your study, in your want
I will put on your jealousy.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.l: It would not
become me to confine your entertainments,
Of friends and visitants, but remember brother,
She's now my sole heir, and by the late death
Or her twin sister, she derives the right
Oh ▪ all my wealth to her, gallants I fear
I'th town hold too fruitful intelligence
In these affairs, and if they be not watched
They'll with their wit charm all the dragon's guard, these golden apples.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.p: There are such indeed.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.l: O sir, there are too many, not a virgin
Left by her friend's heir to a noble fortune,
But she's in danger of a marriage
To some puft title, what are these enter the garden?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: The gentlemen that dined with us —

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Why how now Frank, grown musty on a sudden? Head hung, and playing the thief thus with your friends, to steal your person from us, what's the matter.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Nothing, nothing gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Very like, and yet you leave our company for this nothing.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Let's in again to the ladies.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: What's he.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: One master fowler a reputed wit
I'th town, affected by young gentlemen
For his converse, yet lives upon no pension
But his own fortune, and a fair one.
Th'other Mr. Clare, a friend to Mr. Aymwell, whom they both seem to solicit.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Mr. Aymwell.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: A hopeful gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.l: Brother, did you not observe at dinner
His eyes shoot beams upon my daughter (More
Than I was pleased with) Mr. Aymwell call you him,
I may suspect unjustly, but such looks are often loose conveyors.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Make no part of him your fear.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p:
I do not, when I call to mind my daughter's virtue and obedience,
she knows my purpose to dispose her to sir Nicolas Treedle.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: And how do you find her inclination?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: As I would direct it.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: She will maintain it to your comfort sir,
However with what vigilance becomes me,
I will preserve it, while she remains within my custody.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: I'll leave a servant to wait upon her.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Brains.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: The same.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: He is a cunning fellow.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.l: He has a sconce,
Carries some subtlety which he employs
Still honestly in discharge of any trust committed to him.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.l: And 'tis his pride.
He was ne'er o'er-reached in any action.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: He knows his charge.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.l: Perfectly, but I lose time, sir Nicolas
Treedle expects me, this night i'the country.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: When d'ye return?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.l: Within these three days at most,
Trouble yourself no further.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: I'll wait on you to your horse sir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: Sh'as shot a fire into my bosom, from
Her eye, or I have drawn in, at mine own,
Love poison. O my stars were too ungentle
To point her out the mistress of my thoughts,
Who is so much like them, above the hope
Of ever climbing too, I see a fatal
Impossibility divide us, yet
The more I would discharge this new guest, it
Strengthens itself within me, and renews
Vigour to keep possession, she's above me
And her great fortune makes my expectation
So dull and painful, a great heir her uncle?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Mr. Aymwell what alone, come let's
To cards, where be the gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: Within sir.
Has sir George Richley left us?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Some affairs importuned his departure.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: When shall we expect him?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Three days hence, this your enquiry
Doth promise you have business with him.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: Little,
But you did motion cards, I'll choose my partner
And for a set or two I'm at your service.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Make your own election.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Why d'ye mock me.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: How mock you.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Yes?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: You do not mean in earnest.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: I shall betray my passion.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: I find him.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: You m 'Y for I am lost. Enter Mrs. violet.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: He's here — good uncle, is my father gone?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Yes, gentle niece.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Delight in both your walks
I'll take this arbour.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: So breaks the day and hides itself again
Among the western shades, were she to dwell
Within your garden it should need no sun.
Her smiles were powerful to infuse a warmth
Into the flowers, her breath perfume your arbours
The trees grow rich in blossom and bear fruit
At the same instant, as 'twere ever spring
And ever summer when she seats herself
Within some bower, the feathered quiristers
Shall play their music to her and take pride
To warble airy notes till she be weary,
Which when she shall but with one accent of
Her own express, an hundred nightingales
Shall fall down dead from the soft boughs before her
For grief to be o'erchanted.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Here's pretty madness.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: 'Tis so, you have done my passion justice sir
For love is but a straggling from our reason.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: If you do love my niece, let you and I
Talk out of metaphor.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: You know my father.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: He was my noble friend.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: For his sake, give me your free answer to
One question.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: What is't, promise yourself
what I can do or say is at your service.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: Is there a possibility, admit
I loved your niece, she might be won at last
To be my wife.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: I'll not dispute the extent
Of what is possible, yet my answer may be
Satisfactory.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: You were ever generous.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: I were uncivil not to reply to
A question, you shall find my love more fruitful,
You shall have both my answer and my counsel.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Let me embrace a perfect friend.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: D'ye know what
Fortune my young niece may bring her husband.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: I guess a great one, but I set more value
Upon her person, my affection springs
Not from her wealth.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: But yet her portion
Is worth your taking notice master Aymwell,
Her father is a man who though he write
Himself but knight, keeps a warm house i'th country
Amongst his tenants, takes no lordly pride
To travel with a footman and a page
To London, humbly rides th' old fashion
With half a dozen wholesome liveries,
To whom he gives Christian wages and not countenance
Alone to live on, can spend by th' year
Eight hundred pounds, and put up fine sleeps quietly
Without dreaming on mortgages or statutes
Or such like curses on his land, can number
May be ten thousand pound in ready coin
Of's own, yet never bought an office for't
Has plate no question, and jewels too
In's old lady's cabinet, beside
Other things worth an inventory, and all this
His daughter is an heir too, now pray tell me
What's your revenue?

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Some 3. hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Per annum? Grant it, what expectation
Have you abroad?

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: None.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: That's quickly summoned.
You have not made your love known to my niece yet.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: No, my intention was to preacquaint you.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: You've done wisely, do not think on her
When you're at prayers, she will but puzzle
Your devotion, there's no hope of her.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: I mean for you to arrive at her, your own disparity in fortune.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: I do find it.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Excuse my plainness sir, her father looks
A great deal higher, and to take away
Your least encouragement, to prosecute
Within my knowledge she's designed already
To a wealthy gentleman, and within few days
'Twill be a marriage, you shall but procure
Your own affliction to employ your hope
Where things remain so desperate.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: I thank you.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: You do yourself more right.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: If such affairs
Have passed, it were not noble to continue
This path, you've done me gentle office sir
I must believe you're generous, this new flame
My reason shall suppress, before it grow
Too mighty for me.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: It becomes you well,
Love like to sin, inveterate is strong
He prevents danger, that destroys it young.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Come to your friends. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.l: Your soft stars will not let you be so cruel
Lady, to give repulse to a lover.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Do not believe him, he does but compliment,
I ha' known him court a hundred, with as much
Formality, wooed 'em ith' nuptial cut, made verses
Of their hair, set lilies and roses, a whole
sp.p: Garden i'their cheeks, cherries i'their lips, stellify their eyes, and yet in a twinkling. —

sp.speaker: Penel.
sp.p: Sure you do him wrong sir.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Wrong?

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: He measures my affection by the length of his own, prithee satire choose another walk, and leave us to enjoy this, thou knowest not my intent.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
Thou mayst be honest with one, and that's a miracle
and will ask a strong faith to believe it, I hope she has more wit than to trust your voluble courtship, I'll seek out my friend Aymwell. Vio. comes from the arbour.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Sir, if your engagement require no haste.

sp.speaker: Penel.
sp.p: I do wonder a gentleman of your knowledge should so deceive himself.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Express yourself fairest.

sp.speaker: Penel.
sp.p: Fair sir, I am not taken with your flatteries, I can see through you.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: If you have so active an eye lady, you may see a throng of passions flaming at my heart, set a fire by your beauty I protest t'ee; come, shame not your wisdom to believe report or opinion ath' world, 'tis a malicious age we live in, if your ears have been abused with any ill noise, a me you shall tell yourself if you love me, the world is a shameless and miserable detractor, you do not despise me lady. —

sp.speaker: Penel.
sp.p: No, I pity so handsome a gentleman, and of so fair a fortune, should want his eyes.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: How blind?

sp.speaker: Penel.
sp.p: To your own folly's sir.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Shall I swear I love you, as I am a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: As you are a gentleman, I know you can swear any thing 'tis a fashion you're most constant in, to be religiously wicked, an oath in your mouth and a reservation in your hearts is a common courtship, do not swear as you are a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: As I am an honest man.

sp.speaker: Penel.
sp.p: Out upon't, that's a worse, my tailor cozened me tother day with the same oath, save your credit and let swearing alone, I dare take your word.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Well said.

sp.speaker: Penel.
sp.p: For a greater matter, but not for this, you and I ha' not eaten a bushel of salt yet, in time I may be converted, and think your tongue and heart keep house together, for at this time I presume they are very far asunder.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Would you have my tongue in my heart lady?

sp.speaker: Penel.
sp.p: No by my troth, I would rather find your heart in your tongue, but you are valiant, and 'tis only fear they say, brings a man's heart up to his mouth.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Why, your wit is a tyrant now, pray tell me do not you love me mightily now above potatoes, come I see the little blind boy in your eyes already.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Love you sir?

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Yes, I know by your bitterness you wish me well and think there is some hope I may be won too, you take pains to whip me so handsomely, come I'll be a good child and kiss the rod.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You oblige my service to you, I am one
Aymwell called friend, and shall be happy to
Convey him any knowledge may concern him.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Then briefly thus I understand he loves me
Pray you do him the true office of a friend
And council him desist, I am disposed of
Already in my father's thoughts, and must
Show my obedience, he shall beget
But his own trouble, if he move it to
My uncle or my father, and perhaps
Draw their suspicion and displeasure
On me too, by so indiscreet proceeding,
I would not have a gentleman of his worth
Do himself so great injury to run
A course of so much hazard, if you please
To bear the burden of my thanks for his
On my part undeserved opinion,
And make him sensible, in time he may
Place his affection where he may expect
Better return, you shall discharge a friendship
To him, and with it make my thoughts your debtor.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You have expressed a nobleness in this
Were all of your mind lady,
There would be less willow worn.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: You would ha' me praise you now, I could ramble in your commendation.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: I think so.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p:
D'ye but think so, why you shall hear me, your hairs are Cupid's nets, a forehead like the fairest coast of heaven without a cloud, your eyebrow is love's bow
whiles either eye are arrows drawn to wound, your lips the temple or sacred fane of kisses often as they mere exchanging roses your tongue loves lightning, neck the milky path or throne where sit the graces, do not I know that I have abused you all this while, or do you think I love you a thought the better, or with all my poetical daubings can alter the complexion of a hair now.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: I would not have you sir.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.l: No dispraise te'e
I have seen as handsome a woman
sp.p: Ride upon a sack to market, that never knew the impulsion of a coat or the price of a stammel petticoat, and I ha' seen a worse face in a countess; what's that? Must ye be proud because men do call you handsome, and yet though we are so foolish to tell you so, you might have more wit than to believe it, your eyes may be matched I hope, for your nose there be richer in our sex, 'tis true that you have colour for your hair we grant it, and for your cheeks, but what do your teeth stand you in lady, your lips are pretty but you lay 'em too open and men breathe too much upon 'em, for your tongue we all leave you there's no contesting, your hand is fine but your gloves whiter, and for your leg, if the commendation or goodness of it be in the small, there be bad enough in gentlemen's stockings to compare with it; come remember you're imperfect creatures without a man, be not you a goddess I know you're mortal, and had rather make you my companion then my idol, this is no flattery now.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Where be these gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: How now frank.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: You look well to your charge brains.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: A question sir, pray you, are you married sir?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Why dost thou ask?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Because you should answer me
I cannot see't in your forehead sir,

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: How now my officious trencher squire.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Excuse him master Clare, 'tis his blunt zeal
To do his master service, who enjoyed
His best care and vigilance upon this
Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I am married sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Then I hope you're met with your match already I ha' nothing to say tee.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: This fellow's mad.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Nor my master neither, though he left his brains behind him, I hope a man may ask a question sir.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Come hither brains.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Am life thou art in love.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: You are not.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Do not mistake yourself for I am.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Caught, I am glad on't.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: No indeed not caught neither, therefore be not overjoyed good morality, why dost thou think it possible a woman's face or any thing without her can inchant me.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Let me alone. Exit uncle

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Why dost thou court 'em then.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Why, to try their wits with which I sharpen my own, dost think I am so mad to marry, sacrifice my liberty to a woman, sell my patrimony to buy them feathers and new fashions, and maintain a gentleman usher to ride in my saddle when I am knighted, and pointed at with Pythagoras for my tame sufferance, ha my wardrobe laid forth and my holiday breeches, when my lady pleases I shall take the air in a coach with her, together with her dog that is costïue, be appointed my table what I shall eat, according as her ladyship finds her own body inclined, fed upon this or that melancholy dish by prescription, guarded with officious salads like a prisoner in a throng, praise her beautiful allowance of course mutton that have the world of dainty flesh before me, 'twere a sin oo discretion and my own freedom.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Young mistress, I observe you.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: You do not mean to die in this faith.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p:
Prithee do not talk of dying, a pox o'the bellman and his omnia benes, but that I think I know thy father, I should hardly believe thou wert a gentleman, however
thy Aristotle's of ibi●●● will make thee uncapable of their company shortly, if you catechise thus you shall have few gentlemen your disciples that have any blood or spirit about 'em, there's no discourse so becoming your gallants now, as a horse race or Hyde-park? what lady's lips are softest? what fashion is most terse and courtly? what news abroad? which is, the best vaulting house? where shall we taste canary and be drunk too night, talk a morality — here be ladies still, you shall hear me court one on 'em, I hope you we 'Not report abroad among my friends that I love her, 'tis the love of mounting into her maidenhead I vow Jack, and nothing else.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: You're a mad lover. As Aymwell comes towards Violetta she turns and exit.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: That was cunningly cast about.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Whither is't lady?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: I'm walking in sir.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: I'll wait on you, and after that abroad, 'tis an inviting day, are you for the coach.

sp.speaker: Penel.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Or for the couch? Take me a companion for either.

sp.speaker: Penel.
sp.p: Neither.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.l: How neither, blame yourself if you be idle ▪
Howsoever you shall not be alone, make use of
My arm fairest, you will to your lute, I heard you
Could touch it cunningly, pray bless my ears a little.

sp.speaker: Penel.
sp.p: My lute's broke sir.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: A string you mean, but 'tis no matter, your voice is not, ravish a little with that, if you please I can help you to an heir by this black eye which nature hath given you, I'll not leave you I'll follow ye. Exeunt fowler, and Penelope.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: All this from her?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: You may believe me sir.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: Why this to him, could she not give me
Repulse, but she must thus proclaim it, I never
Moved it to her, her uncle hath had no opportunity
To acquaint her what's the mystery,
Prithee repeat again the substance of what she said.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
With my best memory her words, she wished you
not proceed for she was already disposed of in her father's thoughts.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: In her father's thoughts? Happily not in her own.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: It would be fruitless to move her uncle or her father in't.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: Ha, not move her uncle or her father?
This may beget encouragement hope I may to her
Propound my affection and be happy in't proceed.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: She would be sorry a gentleman of your worth
Should run a course of so much hazard.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Hazard, that word does yet imply there is a possibility.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: So with compliment
Of her thanks for your fair opinion of her,
She wished me make you sensible in time
To place your love where you might expect
Better return.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: Ah that's wormwood, let me see, better return
This last return hath spoiled the whole term
And undone my suit, umh? No it doth admit
A fair construction:
She would ha' me sensible in time to plant
My love where I may expect better return,
Why? That I may from her for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Amantes sibi somnia fingunt, how apt are lovers to construe all to their desires.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: I wonot let my action fall.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Do not build castles.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: I'll smooth it with her uncle, if it hit
O I my blessed stars.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: He's a-bed already.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: Venus assist one to thy altar flies,
And I'll proclaim, thy son hath found his eyes. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena, i.
div.stage: Enter sir Nicholas Treedle, and a servant.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Where's Martext my chaplain.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: He's newly walked out of his meditation in the kitchen, into the garden.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Bid him read prayers in the dining-room.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Before your worship come?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I won't pray too day, dost here? Bid my tutor come down to me.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Which on them.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Why he that reads travail to me, the wit that I took up in Paul's in a tiffany cloak without a hatband, now I have put him into a doublet of satin — stay he's here. Enter tutor.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Morrow tutor, what hour take you it?

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: It is no hour at all sir.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Not directly any hour, for it is between 8. and 9. Sir.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Very learnedly than I was ready between six and sevens too day.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Are you disposed for lecture.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Yes, yes sir.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.l: You remember my last prelection of the division
Of the earth into parts real and imaginary:
The parts real into continent and island,
The subdivision of the continent, into Peninsula,
Isthmus, and promontory.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: In troth sir, I remember some such things but I have forgotten 'em.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: What is an isthmus?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Why an isthmus, is an elbow of land.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: A neck, a neck.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: A neck? Why I was near it, if you had let me alone, I should have come up to't.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: 'Twas well guessed, what's an island?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: An island is an high mountain, which shooteth itself into the sea.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: That's a promontory.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Is't so? An island then is, no matter let it go, 'tis not the first island we ha' lost.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: How are you perfect in your circles? Great and less, mutable and immutable, tropical and polar.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: As perfect in them as I am in these, faith I shall never con these things handsomely, may not a man study travail without these circles, degrees and altilatitudes you speak of?

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Yes, you may.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I do not care for the nearest way, I ha' time enough to go about.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Very well, you shall lay aside your globe then.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Ay, and if please you I will have it stand in my hall to make my tenants wonder instead of the book of martyrs.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: It will do well, now name what kingdom or province you have most mind to.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: What say you to England.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: By no means, it is not in fashion with gentlemen to study their own nation, you will discover a dull easiness if you admire not and with admiration prefer not the weeds of other regiments before the most pleasant flowers of your own garden, let your judgement reflect upon a serious consideration who teaches you the minikin posture of your body, the punctuality of your beard, the formality of your pace, the elbows of your cloak, the heel of your boot, do not other nations? Are not Italian heads Spanish shoulders, Dutch bellies, and French legs, the only notions of your reformed English gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I am resolved to be ignorant of my own country say no more on't, what think you if I went over to France the first thing I did.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: By sea.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: D'ye think I ha' no more wit than to venture myself i'th salt water, I had rather be pickled and powdered at home by half that I had.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: I apprehend you are cautious, it is safe travelling in your study, but I will not read France to you.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: No?

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Pardonne moy it is unnecessary, all the French fashions are here already or rather your French cuts.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Cuts?

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Understand me, there are divers French cuts.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: We have had too many French cuts already.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: First, there is your cut of the head.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: That's dangerous.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Pshaw a hair a hair, a periwig is your French cut and in fashion with your most courtly gallants, your own hair will naturally forsake you.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: A bald reason.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Right observed their prudent and weighty policy who have brought up this artificial headpiece, because no man should appear light headed.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: He had no sound head that invented it.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Then there is the new cut of your doublet or slash the fashion of your apparel a quaint cut.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Upon taffety.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Or what you please, the slash is the emblem of your valour, and besides declareth that you are open breasted.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Open as much as you will but no valour.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Then sir, there is the cut of your leg.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: That's when a man is drunk, is it not?

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Do not stagger in your judgement, for this cut is the grace of your body, I mean dancing o'th French cut i'th leg is most fashionable, believe it pupil a gentile carriage.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: But it is fain to be supported sometime with a bottom. Enter servant.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Here is sir George Richley sir newly alighted.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: O my father in law that shall be.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Then we are cut off.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: There is a match concluded between his daughter and me and now he comes for my answer conduct him to the gallery.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Rather sir meet him.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Let him go before and tell him we are coming and we'll be there as soon as he. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Brains.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: What's the matter.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Let's rifle the other bottle of wine.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Do not endanger thy sconce.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: I'll drink no more.

sp.speaker: Whib.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Because I will not be drunk for any man's pleasure.

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: Drunk?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: 'Tis good English now, was Dutch, may be you ha' some conspiracy upon me.

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: I? Who has betrayed me? his mistress procured the key of the wine-cellar, and bade me try if I could wind up his brains handsomely, he knows on't not one health more.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Not, not, good whible if you urge again I shall suspect.

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: Suspect me?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: And beat you whible if you be not satisfied.

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: I am, but in friendship.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Dost tempt me?

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: I will drink your health and be drunk alone.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p:
This whelp has some plot upon men, I smell powder my young mistress would have blown up my brains this peter-gunner should have given fire, 'tis not the first time she hath conspired so but two not do, I was never yet cozened in my life, and if I pawn my brains for a bottle of sack, or claret, may my nose as a brand for my negligence carry everlasting malmsey in it, and be studded with rubies and carbuncles, mistress you must pardon my officiousness, be as angry as a tiger I must play the dragon and watch your golden fleece, my master has put me in trust and I am not so easily corrupted. I ha' but two eyes Argus had a hundred, but he must be a cunning Mercury must pipe them both asleep I can tell you. And now I talk of sleep, my lodging is next to her chambers, it is a confidence in my master to let his livery lie so near her, serving-men have ere now proved themselves no eunuchs, with their masters daughters, if I were so lusty as some of my own tribe, it were no great labour to commit burglary upon a maiden head, but all my nourishment runs upward into brains and I am glad on't, a temperate blood is sign of a good liver, I am past tilting, here she is with the second part of her to the same tune, another maid that has a grudging
of the green sickness. and wants a man to recover her.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Be this enough between us to bind each to help others designs.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Here's Breynes, he has not yet been drenched.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.p: He is too subtle.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: How now brains?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: As you see forsooth.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Thou art very sad.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: But I am in sober sadness I thank my stars.

sp.speaker: Vi.
sp.p: Witty.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: As much wit as will keep brains from melting this hot weather.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: A dry whore-son not thus to be wrought upon!

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Very good sack and claret ith' house.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Thou hast not tasted.

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.p: Oyes, oyes, my brains swim in canary, exceedingly excellent sack I thank ye ladies, I know 'tis your pleasure I should not want o'th best blood o'th grape in hope there might be a stone in my cup to mar my drinking afterwards. Enter sensible.
Mistress sensible what igge i'the wind she moves so nimbly.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: From whom?

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Master fowler.

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.p: A letter? whence flew that paper kite.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: What this?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: another enclosed without direction happily observed.

sp.speaker: Pen,
sp.p: If you can love I will study to deserve and be happy to give you proof of my service, in the mean time it shall be a testimony of your favour to deliver this inclosed paper to your cousin from her servant Aymwell, farewell and remember fowler, look you cozen what Mr. Fowler writes, I dare trust you with the secret at your opportunity peruse this paper.

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.p:
Conveyances, I read juggling in that paper already, and though you put it up I woe not o, for so much magic to conjure that paper out of her bosom into my pocket now I do long to know what pitiful lover for it
can be no other, is doing penance in that white sheet already, mistress sensible hark ye; whence came that letter?

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: From master fowler to my mistress.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: It is a she letter it seems.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: A she letter why so?

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.p: Because it had a young one it'h belly on't, or I am much mistaken.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Does he not write like a bold gamester?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: And a bowling gamester too, for his bias was towards my mistress, but I may chance to cast a rub in his way to keep him from kissing.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: He hath very good parts in him questionless, but do you love him.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: O the cunning of these gypsies, how when they list they can talk in a distinguishable dialect, they call men foxes but they make, tame geese a some on us, and yet like one a those in Rome I may prove so happy to preserve your distressed Capitol, what news brings this kickshaw.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Master Fowler desires to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.p: Already he might ha' delivered his own letter.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I'll to my chamber

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.p: It will do very well.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I hope you will be careful that I am not troubled with any visit of gentlemen, it will become your officiousness good Dametas to have a care of your charge Pamela.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: So, I can suffer this jeer. Exit.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Ha? is he gone? I'm glad on't, I'll take this opportunity to read the paper, master Aymwell sent me no superscription?

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.p: She's at it already, thus far off I can read her countenance if she spare her voice.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I do not court your fortune but your love,
If my wild apprehension of it, prove
My error, punish gently, since the fire
Came from yourself that kindled my desire.
So my poor heart full of expectance lies
To be your servant or your sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: It shall be answered. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.p: It shall, the games a foot, were I best to discover thus much, or reserve it to welcome home the old knight withal, I'll be more familiar with this juggling, first, the scrivener has a name and if he be worth his own ears he shall be worth my discovery.
Here comes the gallant and the tother toy now.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: I received your letter sir?

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: In good time.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: You might have spared your hand a labour, if you had resolved to put your feet upon this expedition.

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: I confess I wrote something in my own cause, but the chief cause was to convey my friend's affection to his mistress.

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.p: And I will convey your affection to somebody else.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.p: Then you made me a property. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: 'Tis for your honour if you help any way to advance an honest business, and yet mistake me not though the rack should enforce from me without a second reason I had not wrote to you, yet for so much as concerned myself by this kiss, my pen hath but set down the resolution of my heart to serve you.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: To serve me, how?

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: How? why any way, give me your livery I'll wear it, or a coat with a cognizance by this light, I fear you are an heretic still and do not believe as you should do, come let me rectify your faith, serve you ▪

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Since the compliment of service came up, gentlemen have had excuse for their love: I would not have you serve me sir.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Not serve you? Why d'ye think a man cannot love and serve too.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Not one serve two, well.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: You are too literal, and yet i'th strict sense I ha' known a woman has served half a dozen gentlemen handsomely, so, so, and yet the last had enough of her too, why should not one man serve two gentlewomen, it argues against your sex, that you are more insatiable ath' two, but I have a simple affection I protest and individual, I'll ne'er serve but one.

sp.speaker: Penel.
sp.p: But one at once.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: But one at once, and but one always, by this diamond.

sp.speaker: Penel.
sp.p: Nay keep your oath sir.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: I am forsworn if I do not, for I vowed before I came to bestow it, come wear it in your bosom, it shall be an earnest of more precious jewels, though not of so bright a lusty that will follow.

sp.speaker: Penel.
sp.p: I pray sir resolve me one thing, and be plain, do you love me?

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Love you?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: 'Tis my question.

sp.speaker: Fow,
sp.p: 'Tis a very foolish one, to what purpose have I been talking all this while, that you make it a question, has not it been the theme of all my discourse hitherto, that I do love you.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: In what sense?

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: In what sense? Why in any sense at your own choice, or in all the senses together and you doubt me: I do love to see your face, hear your voice, smell your breath, touch your tree, and taste your golden apples.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: But this does not satisfy me.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: You do not doubt my sufficiency dee?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Now you're immodest, I only asked if you love me.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: And ha' not I told you? Pray teach me a better way to express it. Does a wiseman love fool's fortune, and a nobleman another beside my lady? Does the devil love an usurer, a great man his flatterer, the lawyer a full term, or the physician a dead time to thrive in.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Spare yourself this is but course love.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p:
I'll spin it finer and finer every day sweet, to be
plain with thee, what dost thou think of me for a husband, I love thee that way.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Would you did else.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Is there my thing in me would commend itself, that I may spare my other commendations, for I am resolved to be yours at any rate of my own praise, or what I can purchase from my friends.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Sir, if your meaning be no stranger to your language, although I cannot promise myself, you bind me to be thankful for it.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: She nibbles already.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: But pardon me if I suspect you still, you are too wild and airy to be constant to that affection.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: There be the pigeons.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: An't be no worse I care not, Mr. Fowler
A most welcome friend.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: I would be to your daughter.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Let her use to entertain him so, and he'll bid himself welcome, hark you sir, you do like his company?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: So I say, but if I were worthy to give your daughter counsel she should have a special care how she treads, for if this gentleman be not a whoremaster, he is very like one; and if she chance any way to crack her venice-glass, 'twill not be so easily soldered.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Meddle with your charge sir, and let her alone.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: I have done, here is a fresh gamester. Enter mr. Manley.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: By your noble leave.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: You're welcome sir.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I was directed hither to find a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Manly how is't?

sp.speaker: Manl.
sp.p: I was to inquire for you at your lodging.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Pray know this gentleman lady master worthy he'll deserve your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: You oblige my services — but what make you here my woman ferreter.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Come hither Penelope.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Soliciting a cause of Venus.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I suspect as much, but with her? is she a whore?

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.l: No but I'll do the best to make her one,
She loves me already, that's some engagement
I dare trust thee with my sins, who's here
Aymwell and Clare. Enter Mr. Aymwell, Mr. Clare, brains.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Withdraw yourself.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Frank.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Master worthy.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: A knot of friends.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: What of my letter?

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: 'Tis delivered you must expect.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: What news gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: We hear none, you visit the exchange sir, pray furnish us.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: What do all these butterflies here, I do not like it.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: I hope your daughter is in health.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Perfect, I thank heaven.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: And your niece at whose naming I'm bold to tender my thanks for your last friendship, I might have plunged by this time into passion had not you nobly, just as I was falling prevented my unhappiness.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Your opinion of what I did, gives value to the action, however 'twas a duty I was bound to.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: This is the youth, I'll pawn my brains, hark you sir, what do you call this gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Master Aymwell.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: He may shoot short for all his aiming,
He wears bachelors buttons does he not.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: Yes, old trupeny and loops too, thou art jealous now.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: One word more.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: I have a plot and thou must help me.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Let it be a safe one.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: May we not see her?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Brains where's thy mistress?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: She's a little busy.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Who's that.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: My niece.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: And she be but a little busy she's more than half at leisure.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p:
Do not you know that a woman is more troubled
with a little business, than some man with managing the troubles of a whole common wealth, it has been a proverb, as busy as a hen with one chicken, marry and she had twenty, twenty to one she would not be so fond on 'em.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: He says right, gentlemen, we are friends, it is my brother's pleasure who is her father, to deny frequent access to her, till he hath finished a design, for my part, I am not of his mind, nor shall my daughter be a prisoner to his fancy, you see sir I do not seclude her, if she choose within any limits of reason, I move in her.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: You speak nobly.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Sir George Richley sir, and sir Nicholas are newly arrived.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: My brother, acquaint my niece.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: 'Tis my office I'll do it —Exit.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Shall's stay?

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: By all means let's see the doughty knight that must free the lady from her enchanted castle.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Didst ever see him?

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: No, but I have heard his character.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Prithee let's have't.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p:
They say he's one, was wise before he was a man for then his folly was excusable, but since he came to be of age, which had been a question till his death, had not the law given him his father's lands, he is grown wicked enough to be a landlord, he does pray but once a year and that's for fair weather in harvest, his inward senses are sound, for none comes from him he speaks words but no matter, and therefore is in election to be of the peace and quorum, which his tenants think him fit for, and his tutor's judgement allows, whom he maintains to make him legs and speeches, he feeds well himself, but in obedience to government, he allows his servants fasting days; he loves law, because it killed his father, whom the
parson overthrew in a case of tithes; and in memory, wears nothing suitable, for his apparel is a or the ruins of ten fashions, he does not much care for heaven, for he's doubtful of any such place, only hell he's sure of, for the devil sticks to his conscience, therefore he does purpose when he dies, to turn his sins into almshouses, that posterity may praise him for his bountiful of hot pottage, but he's here already, you may read the rest as he comes towards you. Enter sir George, sir Nicholas, tut.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Brother.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Let your kindest respects meet this gentleman.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Sir Nicholas Treedle, I desire you would write me in the number of your servants.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: 'Tis granted, gentlemen I have an ambition to be your eternal slave.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: 'Tis granted.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: And I to be an everlasting rascal.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: 'Tis granted.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: A couple of Cockaloches.

div.stage: Enter Penelope, Violetta, Winifred, sensible, and Breines.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Here comes my daughter.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Lady and mistress of my heart, which hath long melted for you.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: This is my daughter.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Then it melted for you lady.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: His heart is whole again.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Vouchsafe to entertain a servant, that shall study to command.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Well said.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: His extremest possibilities — in your business.

sp.speaker: Aymw.
sp.p: Abominable courtship.

sp.speaker: Sens.
sp.p: Sir, I am servant to mistress Violetta, who commends this paper to you.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: O my best angel.

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.p: As the devil would have it, are you there sensible.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Mr. worthy I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Will you not stay supper.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: We are engaged.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: My service shall wait on you gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Clare
sp.p: And mine.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Come on my Queen of diamonds.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Master worthy I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Will you not stay supper.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: We are engaged.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: My service shall wait on you gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And mine.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Come on my Queen of diamonds.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Brother lead the way. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: If she carry away this letter so, call me shallow-brains, I was never yet cozened in my life, this night? it shall be so, I will not come with bare relation of your plots ▪
sp.l: I'll bring active intelligence that shall tell
Your secret aims, so crush 'em in the shell.

div.head: Scaena, i.
div.stage: While the music is playing enter breynes without his shoes with a letter in his band.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Sure this is it, my mistress and her maid are both fast still, I ha' watched under the bed all night, to rob her pocket of this paper, and I ha' don't, some fellow at this opportunity would have wriggled himself into one of their flesh.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Who's there? Sensible.

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.p: Death her tongue is awake already.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Who's i'the chamber.

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.p: Help me brains, before she wakes the tother, 'tis I forsooth but looking for the chamberpot. Counterfeits sensibles voice.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Beshrew you for your noise.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Where's the door — stumbles.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: The tother spirit is raised i'th trundlebed
What will become o'me now. Enter sensible.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Here's nobody .

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Make an end and get thee to bed.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: An end of what, does she talk in her sleep, she was not wont.

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.l: So, so, ha the spring is open
I might forget to make it fast last night,
'Tis so, and happily some cur or cat
Has been i'the chamber, for I hear a noise
About the door, I'll make it fast
And so to bed again, I think it is day already. Exit.

div.stage: Enter tutor in his gown as from his study.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.l: So this fancy wrote, for sir Nicholas like a forked
Arrow points two ways, wenches are caught with
Such conceits, they will imagine't none of his
Invention, than whose but mine my person does invite
More acceptation, but the father aims
At the estate, no matter if I can
Insinuate myself into her opinion
'Tis no impossibility, her portion
Will be enough for both, shall I live still
Dependant and not seek ways to advance my
Self, busy my brains in ballads to the giddy
Chambermaids, beggar myself with purse and pincase
When she that is the mistress may be mine
'Twill be a master piece if I can gull him,
But he's here already. Enter sir Nicholas.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: Noble tutor, morrow to you, hay finished
The whimsy for my mistress already?

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: I ha' don't, this paper carries the love powder.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: For fear you had forgotten me, I ha' made a quibbling in praise of her myself, such a one as will fetch up her heart tutor.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: That were a dangerous vomit sir, take heed of that.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I but I will not hurt her I warrant thee, and she die within a twelvemonth and a day I'll be hanged for her.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Will you sir.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Marry will I, look you sir. But first let me see yours, can you not write it in my own hand, I shall hardly read it.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: I'll read it to you.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Sir George give me't.

div.stage: Enter sir George, and m. Worthy.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: See they are at it.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: And how do you like it.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Morrow noble sir Nicholas.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Morrow gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Morrow to you both, sir George I ha' been making poetry this morning.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: He has a subtle fancy.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: What's the subject?

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: No subject, but the Queen of his affections.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I scorn subjects, 'tis my empress your daughter's muse hath set my muse on fire.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Read sir.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: No, you shall read 'em for me.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: 'Tis a hue and cry sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: A hue and cry, for what?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: For what, why for somewhat I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: You may call it loves hue and cry.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Call it what you will, I know what 'tis.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Are you so poetical.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I ha' been dabbling in Helicon, next to travail 'tis all my study mark the invention.

lg.l: In love's name you are charged hereby
To make a speedy hue and cry,
After a face who tother day
Came and stole my heart away;
For your directions in brief
These are best marks to know the thief:
Her hair a net of beams would prove,
Strong enough to captive Jove:
Playing the eagle, her clear brow
Is a comely field of snow,
A sparkling eye, so pure a grey
As when it shines it needs no day:
Ivory dwelleth on her nose
Lily married to the rose,
Have made her cheek the nuptial bed
Lips betray their virgin's weed
As they only blushed for this
That they one another kiss,
But observe beside the rest
You shall know this felon best
by her tongue, for if your ear
Shall once a heavenly music hear
Such as neither gods nor men
But from that voice shall hear, again
That that is she, o take her t'ee
None can rock heaven asleep but she.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: How do you like my pippin of Parnassus gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ric. Wor.
sp.p: Very handsome.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Nam, I'll warrant you, my tutor has good furniture in him.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: I do not think he made 'em.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Now you shall hear some verses of my own making.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Your own, did you not make these?

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: He betrays himself.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Hum? yes I made 'em too my tutor knows.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: I'll take my oath who made 'em.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: But I wrote 'em for another gentleman that had a mistress.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: My daughter you said.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I may say so, but that their faces are nothing alike, you would hardly know one from tother, for your better understanding I will read 'em myself — her foot.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: D'ye begin there?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: O, I will rise by degrees.
Her foot is feat with diamond toes
But she with legs of ruby goes:
Thighs loadstones, and do draw unto her
The iron pin of any wooer.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Precious conceit.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Her head.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Her head?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: You were between her thighs but now.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: 'Tis my conceit, I do now mean to go downwards again, and meet where I left in the middle.

lg.l: Her head is opal, neck of sapphire,
Breast carbuncles, shine like a fire.
And the naked truth to tell you,
The very mother of pearl her belly:
How can she choose but hear my groans,
That is composed of precious stones.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.p: I marry sir.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Now if you liked you may.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.p: A word with you sir, pray what d'ye think of your pupil.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: I think nothing sir.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.p: But deal ingeniously, your opinion.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Shall I tell you?

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.p: Pray sir.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.p: I think so too, what doth my brother mean to make this fond election.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: For my own part you hear me say nothing, but the good parts and qualities of men are to be valued.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.p: This fellow's a knave, I smell him.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Some thing has some savour.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.l: When you please, name your own time
I'm ready to be married at midnight.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: About a seven-night hence.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Let it be 3. or 4. I care not how soon, is breakfast ready.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: It waits upon you.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I do love to eat and drink in a morning, though I fast all day after.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: I'll follow brother.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.p: We'll both attend. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Aymwell with a letter.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: This opportunity, let my covetous eye,
Take to enrich itself, but first prepare
With reverence, as to an altar bring
No careless but religious beams along
With you to this new object, this small paper
Carries the volume of my humane fate
I hold my destiny, betwixt two fingers
and thus am I wrapped up without a name
Being or expectation of world's joy
More than this table (When the curtains drawn)
Presents in character to my thirsty eye sight,
Hail thou ambassador from thine and my
Mistress, bringing peace or unkind war
Thou emblem of her whiteness which I kiss
And thus again salute. Enter boy and Clare.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Then he's alone.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: So leave us.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: Coming from her
Can it be guilty of defiance to me
Had she not meant me happy she had given
My letter to the flame, and with it I
In those thin ashes had been buried,
Nor had she deigned this answer with the circumstance
At my receiving prompts me to believe
Gracious the gentle messenger command it
Not as a thing she wooed a public, but
With eyes full of suspicion which had been
Needless, had she contemned my service.
So smilingly departed, thus I sent my paper
Which what but love taught her to imitate
Without a superscription, o Clare welcome,
Welcome to that heart dance i'thy bosom
If thou beest a friend and canst rejoice to know me
Happy, you thought me ridiculous and that I did
With too much flattery of myself, expound your story
Had I been like thee of frosty apprehension and cold
Phlegmatic judgement, I had missed a blessing
That wanton Jove would have been rival for
Dost see this paper?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Nothing in the outside.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: 'Tis inly precious.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You have not searched the
Lining that you promise so.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: I see through it, hast thou not heard the perfect magnes
Will although enclosed within an ivory box,
Through the white wall shoot forth embracing virtue
to the loved needle, I can read it Clare
And read a joy in't that transports me, this
Came from my mistress, having touched her hand
Whence it received a whiteness hath it not
Brought incense to dipersing a rich breath
Sweeter than Arabian spicery
About the room, in which while it remains
We suck in perfumed air, it came from her
My honest Clare, from her she whose rare wit taught
When in thy dull opinion I was lost,
My apprehension a new hope to thrive
In my ambitious love, excellent women
The top of all creation I shall be
At once too happy, unrip thou the seal
Read it, and let thy voice convey it gently
Lest I be surfeited, but why should any
Be honoured to receive her
But I, to whom she hath directed it,
By thy leave silent paper, confident
Of bless I open my Elysium
And let my soul into it — ha.Reads
Laden with mighty hopes how despondent
Have I launched forth and find a storm.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What's this? Your own letter returned
Can it be otherwise than in scorn.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: In scorn.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Ha you not now cause of triumph, who is now the truer prophet, you would nourish hope in spite of reason, now you feel a punishment in her derision.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Is this credible.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Credible? 'tis no wonder in a woman
Though she had promised, vowed affection to you
It had not been a miracle to find
A change in their affection, yet you cannot
Accuse her much.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: Appeared I so unworthy
That among so many ways she had to express
At what poor value she esteemed my proffered
Service, her pride could find out none but this
to send me mine own again.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Do but imagine
You sent a servant with a message to her,
She not within, he is returned again
Without an answer.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: Incivility,
She might have thanked me, and subscribed her name,
I was not bound to her observance.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Come be free again.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: I will be so, with this
That I could cancel my affection.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What do you mean, it having touched her hand
Is full of incense and Arabian spicery
You are too prodigal of your perfume.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Do not thou mock me too.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Well, I ha' done.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: Would I had so I cannot empty all
My torment, wherefore should a man love woman
Such airy mockeries, nothing but mere echoes
That owe their being to our opinion
And in reward of honouring them, send back
As scornfully the language we bestowed.
Out of our too much dotage.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: If they send,
All they receive from us, accuse them not
We have our hearts again.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: And I'll have mine,
I will, I ha' not yet, here wants a guest
Invite him home again, why should not I
Be as coy as she, and with as much neglect
Throw her behind my thoughts, instruct me with
Witty revenge, and thou that see me toss
This shuttlecock with as much pride, and when
I'm sated with this sport, let fall this vanity
Into as low disdain, pshaw.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Nobly resolved.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: Come to a tavern, drench the memory
Of these poor thoughts.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Let's seek out master
Fowler and manly.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: And warmed with sack, we'll try
Who can make satires best.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: A match, let's to 'em.

div.stage: Enter master Fowler, Manly like his physician.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: And thou dost not play the doctor handsomely, I'll set the college of physicians upon thee for practising without a licence.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Can you be sick?

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: I would but counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: So must I the physician.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: I have known a spruce empiric hath given his patient 2 or 3. stools with the bare repetition of crude words, and knotty sentences, which have come from him like a phlegm, which besides the operation in the hearers, who admire him for't, while he beats like a drum, at their barrel head, and turns their brains like beer, does him the benefit to scour his own dirty maw, whose dregs else would putrify; and infest his cheeks worse than a gangrene.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Are you sure she will visit you?

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: As sure as I am well, for and I were sick and would sleep, I would rather, take a nap o'th ridge of Aetna, and thee fall of deafning Nilus, then endure the visitation, of any of their tribe — one knocks, my pillow and lay my head in the aching posture. One knocks

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: 'Tis Aymwell and Clare.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Where's my witty Bacchanalian, how now? what means this apothecary's shop about thee, art physical?

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Sick, sick.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Didst not look in a glass today? how scurvily this nightcap shows upon thee.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: What's the disease?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: A fever sir.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Hang fevers, let's to the tavern, and inflame ourselves, with lusty wine, suck in the spirit of sack, till we be Delphic and prophecy my bully rook.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Alas.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Alas, is that the disease, drench her, drench her in sack, sick for a lass, do not fool thyself beyond the cure of bedlam, be wise and well again.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: You are merry, it seems you have won the lady.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p:
What lady? the lady ith' lobster, I was half
sick for foolish thing called a woman, a toy took me i'th head, and had like to have taken away my heart too but I ha' recovered, do not trust thy body with a physician, he'll make thy foolish bones go without flesh in a fortnight, and thy soul walk without a body a seven night after.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: These are no doctors?

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: Doctor! art a Parisian, a Paduan, or a leaden doctor?
How many and be true to us hast thou killed the last
Spring, will it puzzle thy arithmetic, my precious
Rectifier of nature, the wrong way, — faith
Thou must excuse me Jack that I cannot condole
With thee, by this whey beard of Esculapius, I dare
Not endanger myself with so much melancholy
Lest I fall into a relapse — whom have we here?

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.p: 'Tis reported that master Fowler is sick and keeps his chamber, I hope he's within.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Noble sir.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Fair lady.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: How fare you sir?

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: The better to see you here.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Upon the entrance of this gentlewoman, I find your grief much altered.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Upon mine?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes, and by that I dare presume to say you are the cause of his distemper.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: I sir?

sp.speaker: Pow.
sp.p: A cunning doctor

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: For I observed so soon as his searching eye had fastened on her, his labouring pulse that through his fever did, before stick hard, and frequent now exceeds in both these differences and this Galen himself found true upon a woman, that had doted upon a fencer.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I?

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: She did long for tother bout then,

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Give us leave pray.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: A very pretty fellow,

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Well skilled i'th pulse.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: You know my disease too d'ye not? will not my complexion give you the hint on't

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: You are not very well.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: How sir?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: By your favour you will come to't.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: To what?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: To a burning fever — is there not one woman in the world.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: I think there is, and too much of that, what then what conclude you?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Nothing but syrup of violet, would comfort you going to bed.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Violet?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Has given't you.

sp.speaker: Fow:
sp.p: It does me good lady to feel you by — the hand.

sp.speaker: Pen:
sp.p: Would it were in my power to recover you.

sp.speaker: Fow:
sp.p: The doctor I thank him has taken pains with me, but he says — nothing will do me good.

sp.speaker: Pen:
sp.p: Nothing?

sp.speaker: Fow:
sp.p: But that, which is another sickness to reveal.

sp.speaker: Pen:
sp.p: Pray sir acquaint me.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: I know you love me.
I have a great mind and 'twere but for two or 3. Minutes, to have a maid warm my bed.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: That may be done.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: With her body — else 'twill do me no good the doctor says — to put life in some of my limbs, a little virgin warmth would do't.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: You have a burning fever.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: But now and then I have such cold fits again — and 'tis the doctor's opinion — a very learned man.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: A learned pander.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: He's at it.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Doctor.

sp.speaker: Cla ..
sp.p: Again passionate.

sp.speaker: Aym:
sp.p: Why, I may love her name without offence, to you, why did he waken my remembrance I had forgotten her.

sp.speaker: Cla:
sp.p: Think upon her scorn then.

sp.speaker: Aym:
sp.p: I ha' done, and till I hear her name again I will throw this dulness off.

sp.speaker: Cla:
sp.p: Let's choose another subject
How closely they consult, the doctor is in a fit of counsel I suspect some juggling — he comes of, I'll gauge a limb this fellow's an impostor.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Is there not much danger in him?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Within two minutes gentlemen, I have discovered happier symptoms.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: What crotchets be these, the fellows mad I think.

sp.speaker: Vio:
sp.l: O look sensible seek everywhere
About the chamber, I ha' lost the letter
Aymwell sent me, if we should be
Discovered, we are quite undone, what's that in thy hand,

sp.speaker: Sen:
sp.p: A letter.

sp.speaker: Vio:
sp.p: Whence.

sp.speaker: Sen:
sp.p: I know not was left here, and Breines having some business to dispatch requested me to deliver it.

sp.speaker: Vio:
sp.p: Let me see't. To the right worshipful sir George richly, I see him coming, lose no time, employ thy diligence to search for mine, I will deliver this.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: I shall mistress.

sp.speaker: Vio:
sp.l: My father presses me to marry Treedle
Short time's allowed for the preventionEnter sir geo.
My good angel assist me, here's a letter sir.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Whence.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I know not, your servant Breines received it.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: What's here — daughter do not you know whence this letter came?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Not I sir.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: You cannot be so ignorant.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: What means my father?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: You are familiar with the contents.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I beseech you sir have no suspicion. —

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: I'll read it to you, Mr. Aymwell; I received your letter, and praise your apprehension, upon the first view of your person, I conceived opinion of your merit, the flame is now too great to be suppressed, it is no time to protract your hopes nor dishonour in me to yield upon noble conditions at the first summon, I accept your love, and require your industry to prevent my father's purpose, my servant sensible you may trust, I will use some invention to delay my expected marriage, farewell.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: My harsh fate.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: D'ye know this character, where's my man brains.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Your man devil. Enter brains.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Did your worship call?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: O my best servant.
Does not thy very soul blush to deceive me.

sp.speaker: Bra:
sp.p: What's the matter mistress.

sp.speaker: Vio:
sp.p: Hear me I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Geo:
sp.l: I'th height and puzze of my care to make
Thee, happy? to conspire thy overthrow
I won't hear.

sp.speaker: Bra:
sp.p: Good sir.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: This was your work you can read.

sp.speaker: Bra:
sp.p: And write too the superscription of a letter or so.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Where's sensibleEnter sensible.
For your good service to your mistress housewife
Pack up your trinkets, I here discharge you.

sp.speaker: Bra:
sp.p: I hope you are sensible.

sp.speaker: Vio:
sp.p: O wench my father hath my letter.

sp.speaker: Sen:
sp.p: Yours?

sp.speaker: Vio:
sp.p: And I mistaking sealed and returned Aymwell that which he sent.

sp.speaker: Sen:
sp.p: How came he by't.

sp.speaker: Vio:
sp.p: Talk not of that, o for some art to help us.

sp.speaker: Bra:
sp.p: Let me council you not to express any violence in your passions, lest you mar the possibility of reclaiming her, it seems Aymwell has missed the intelligence, where shame is enforced too much upon the delinquent, it begets rather an audacious defence of the sin, than repentance, soft rain slides to the root, and nourishes, where great storms make a noise, wet but the skin a'th earth, and run away in a channel.

sp.speaker: Sen:
sp.p: A most rare project.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: It will appear the same, both made together
Which since my sister's death I have worn.

sp.speaker: Geo:
sp.p: Which of my cares reward'st thou with this folly.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Sir can you pardon?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: I love you but too well, go to your chamber.

sp.speaker: Vio:
sp.p: But must we part.

sp.speaker: Geo:
sp.p: Dispute it not.

sp.speaker: Bra:
sp.p: Bye sweet mistress sensible, I hope we shall meet again as merry as we part.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: 'Tis very violent, but we obey your pleasure, I have only apparel and some few trifles.

sp.speaker: Geo:
sp.p: Take 'em all w'ye and be gone.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Beside my own misfortune, I have cause to pity thine, my father is displeased, and not injustly, happy genius. —Exeunt

sp.speaker: Geo:
sp.p: So, things must be managed wisely, I will hasten the marriage.

sp.speaker: Bra:
sp.p: By all means let it be sudden.

sp.speaker: Geo:
sp.p: Within two days — tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Bra:
sp.p: I won't sleep, till she be married, but carry things smooth, let not the knight suspect you're troubled, your daughter will be fetched about with a bias again.

sp.speaker: Geo:
sp.p: How thou deservest me, let us in.

sp.speaker: Bra:
sp.l: Hereafter for my sake, and subtle pains
Who ere is wise, let the world call him brains.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Can this be true?

sp.speaker: Sen:
sp.p: As I have faith to heaven.

sp.speaker: Aym:
sp.l: Take this and this for thy sweet story, thou
Hast entranced me with thy language; laden
With my despairs, like a distressed bark
I gave myself up lost in the imagined
Tempest ▪ but at point of striking
Upon a rock, what a celestial gale
Makes my sails swell with comfort, and enforcing
My ship into the channel, I do feel it
Bound on the waves, discretion at the helm
Which passion made forsaken, I now bless
The minute I weighed anchor; o my destiny
Dwell longer on this thread and make it firm,
upon it hangs the weight of such a fortune
That if it crack, will swifter than Jove's flaming
Arrow, dig my grave i'th earth's centre ▪
Forgive me sacred sex of women that
In thought or syllable I ha' declaimed
Against your goodness, I will redeem it
With such religious honouring your names
That when I die some near thought stained virgin
Shall make a relic of my dust, and throw
My ashes like a charm upon those men,
Whose faithes they hold suspected, to what pitch
Of blessedness are my thoughts mounted.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: Sir,
This is an opportunity for action
Time will run fast upon the minute.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: Pardon
The trespass of my joy it makes me vild
I am too well rewarded for thy suffering
Promise thyself a noble recompense.

sp.speaker: Man:
sp.p: Come ha you finished your discourse yet.

sp.speaker: Aym:
sp.l: You're my friends,
I was deceived in my Violetta
She loves, sh'as sent me proof, but a mistake
Sent back my letter, and detained her answer
Which was betrayed to her father, but keep your wonder
To honour her rare wit, which if the stars
Show themselves not malicious, will assure
All my desires in her, a divine project
She is the master engine, you must work too,
Will you not friends?

sp.speaker: Both:
sp.p: You know you may command us.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: Then spread your bosoms, you shall straight procure
A caroche be ready a'th backside a'my lodging,
Do not lose time in questioning, my fate
Depends upon your haste.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Promise it done.

sp.speaker: Aym:
sp.p: You shall disguise yourself I must employ you in rougher action.

sp.speaker: Clar:
sp.l: I refuse no office
To advance your hopes.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: My certainty's, in thee,
the frame of our whole building leans, come on
Move slowly time until our work be done. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I was not blind to your deserts.
Nor can be so ungrateful now, as not
To give encouragement to your affection
My father may command my person, never
My love to marry Treedle.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: He's an ass I made his best verses for 'em.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I thought his fancy would not reach 'em.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: His sconce is drier than a pumice.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: There be ways to prevent marriage for I'm already changed.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: You're wise, let's run away together.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: But how shall I be sure your love is firm.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Try me and trust me after.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: And I will, for shall it be a hard task I'll impose on you, dare you fight?

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: If I like my enemy.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: 'Tis a poor old fellow.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Then I'll kill him, his name?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: My father's servant brains.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.l: He's dead.
By this time.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Stay, there is a circumstance
To be observed, by some means I'll procure
He waits on me to the strand this afternoon.
Sir Nicholas? your ear for the rest.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.l: He will suspect nothing by our privacy,
He bade me take occasion to urge
His good parts to you, should he ask I'd swear
I did but press his commendations.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Is thy name whible.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Yes, an't please your worship.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I like thee the better for that my name's Treedle.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: I thank your worship.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Hast done hooking a me.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Every eye hath his object already.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: A witty knave, what place dost thou occupy under thy master.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: I am commonly his journeyman sir.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: I look to his horse's sir.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Wilt serve me when I'm married.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Alas, I have no good parts to commend men.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: No good parts, and thou hast but skill in horses and dogs, thou'rt fit for any gentleman in England.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Just at that place assault him.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: By your fair hand I will.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: My delight, how fare you.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I'm studying some witty poesy for thy wedding ring, let me see —

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Trouble not your head, whible entreat my father hither.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: No matter, I will send to the university.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Were you ever of any college?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: College, I have had a head in most ath' butteries of Cambridge, and 't has been sconced to purpose. I know what belongs to sizing and have answered to my que in my days, I'm free of the whole university, I commenced with no worse than his majesty's footmen.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: And ever since you have had a running wit, you were better consult our wits at home, we have excellent poets i'th town they say.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I'th town? What makes so many scholars then come from Oxford and Cambridge, like market women with dorsers full of lamentable tragedies, and ridiculous comedies which they might here vent to the players, but they will take no money for 'em.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: O my dearest! How happy shall I be when I'm married. Kiss.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Look, they are engendering at the lip.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: I like it well.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Why are our joys deferred?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: But till tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: 'Tis an age methinks .

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Kind worm.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: This cannot be deceit.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I want some trifles the exchange will furnish me, let it be your motion to my father.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p:
Father and uncle you will excuse our fa●●li●e conversation; I vow I'll be honest till I be married, nor as
touch of my flesh within the walls, only the suburbs of her lips or hands, or so, and when, and when is tomorrow the day, the day of coupling and so forth, have you got a licence.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: It shall be my next work:

sp.speaker: Nic.
