sp.p: Pray do, we'll be married here, but keep our wedding at my own house at Croidon, we'll ha' the city waits down with us, and a noise of trumpets, we can have drums i'th country, and the train-band, and then let the Spaniards come and they dare, dost hear; here's twenty pieces you shall fribble 'em away at the exchange presently.

sp.speaker: Geo:
sp.p: How sir?

sp.speaker: Nic:
sp.p: By this gold she shall father, lay it out in toothpicks, I'll wear 'em out in my hat; come I'll with you for the licence.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Who shall with her?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: I must attend a project of my daughters. Exit.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Brains.

sp.speaker: Bra:
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Geo:
sp.p: Wait on my daughter to the exchange, observe her carefully.

sp.speaker: Bra:
sp.p: Point me a minute to return with her, if I fail put my brains into'th pot, and let 'em be served up with a calf's head, tomorrow dinner.

sp.speaker: Vio:
sp.p: It succeeds to my wish.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Violetta, look you lay out my gold at the exchange in Bartholomew fairings, farewell Violetta.

sp.speaker: Bra:
sp.p: Come mistress will you walk, I would fain see any mortal wit cozen me a my charge now, I will live to be the shame of politicians, and when I am dead, be clapped up into the chronicles.

sp.speaker: Fow:
sp.p:
Ah the desire of unlawful flesh, what a conjuring dost thou keep within us to lay this little spirit of conscience, the world and the devil, are tame and sprightless
temptations, poor traffic to this staple commodity of whoring: this is the place where I must take shipping for the summer islands, if she keep touch, I will call them fortunate, and once a week make a love voyage to them. Ha! are we entertained with music?

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: Back, back again, fond man forbear,
Buy not a minute's play too dear:
Come with holy flame and be
Welcome to virtue and to me.

sp.p: Come with holy flame and be, welcome to virtue and to me? Flame? I bring none wi' me, and I should be sorry to meet any fire works here, for those hereafter I look on 'em afar off, and apprehend them with less fear, again?

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: Love a thousand sweets distilling,
And with nectar bosoms filling,
Charm all eyes that none may find us,
Be above, before, behind us;
And while we thy pleasures taste
Enforce time itself to stay,
And by forelock hold him fast
Lest occasion slip away.

sp.p: I marry, this is another manner of invitement, I'll to her but —Enter Winifrid.here comes the squire of her mistress's body, how does my little taper of virgin wax, thou hast been in some damp thou burnest blue methinks .

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Noble sir.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: What, a cold.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: A great cold, I ha' lost my voice.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: And thou hast not lost thy maidenhead 'tis no matter, have a little care of thy Frank ▪ tenement, and thy tongue will come time enough to itself I'll warrant thee, what place has she chosen for the encounter?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Her chamber.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Her chamber?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: 'Tis all dark.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Is't all dark, I commend her policy the better, than the room, and the deed that must be done in't will be of one complexion, so she be light I care not, prithee convey me to her.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Follow me.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: As thy shadow woe be to some a the dear sex when a chambermaid is usher to a gentleman. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: It shall be a harmless trial sir.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Go too, I know thou art virtuous, put in execution thy purpose, I'll be within the reach of thy voice.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: It shall be my security,
What ill star, ruled at my nativity,
That I should be so miserable to love
A man, whose glory is his vice, whose study
Is but to ruin virtue. Enter Winifrid.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Mistress?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Here Winifrid.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: The gamester waits his entrance jocund as a bridegroom, he has forgotten his fever.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Away you know your charge, be ready where are you sir, Mr. fowler she speaks hoarse. Enter Fowler.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Hell, if darkness will carry it, yet hell cannot be so black.
There are too many flames in't, thy hand, what monks hole hast thou brought me to, where's thy mistress.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: This is the way.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Is this the way? it is a very blind one, the devil can hardly know me if he meet me here that's my comfort, yet if he did, he loves the sin too well to interrupt so precious a meeting, prithee child of darkness conduct me to the handsome fairy I must dance withal.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: It seems your fever hath left you.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p:
My fever, I forget myself, I should have counterfeited sick all this while, but no matter and thy mistress know it not, thou art skilful in secrets, and I will deserve it: two or 3. ●i●s when I am in her presence, will make her keep her
promise, wi'me about the cure, for that she thinks I was so, prithee do thy office and bring me to her, I hope she is not within hearing.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Fear not.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: So about it then.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: There's a fee belongs to my place first:

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: A fee belonging to your place, as I hope for a limb of thy mistress I had forgotten it, there's gold I can feel it by this darkness: for thou seest I have no light to swear by 'tis weight, quick periwinkle to thy mistress now.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: This is not enough.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: There's more, take silver and all.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: This is nothing.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Is it nothing? by this hand would I could see't, 'tis all I have, wilt search me?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: There is another fee belongs to us.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Another fee belongs to us? what's that? I must kiss her, thou'st a down lip, and dost twang it handsomely, now to the business.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: This is not all I look for:

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: She won't tempt me to come aloft will she?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: If you could see me I do blush;

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: What does my daughter mean?

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: If I could see her she does blush she; says 'tis so: o the insatiable desires of chambermaids! they were wont to look no higher than the groom or servingman and be thankful, or if the master would be pleased to let 'em show him this lobby tother withdrawing chamber, or the turret in summer, and take occasion to commend the situation and so forth, 'twas after the lady had been served, out of his own mere motion and favour, and 'twas taken as an endearment for ever of their service and secrecy, now they must be tasters to 'em i'the sweet sin, fees o'the court must be paid, or no suit commenced with iniquity, oh Venus, what will this world come to?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Hear me.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.l: Yes, I cannot see thee.
Wash thy polluted soul.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: I like this well
And find her noble aim.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Be man again;
For yet thou art a monster, and this act
Published will make thee appear so black and
Horrid, that even beasts will be ashamed
Of thy society, my goodness in hope of
Your conversion makes me chides you so,
Ha Winifrid dost thou observe him, o my heart
Is full of fear, I tremble to look on him:
See of a sudden what a paleness has
Possessed his face ▪ do not his eyes retire
Into their hollow chambers, sir how do you?

sp.speaker: Fow:
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: What new project's this?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: A sudden change.
Sure heaven is just unto thy late imposture,
And thou art punished now indeed with sickness
For mocking heaven I fear, o dost thou see.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Death sits upon his forehead, I never saw
The horror of a dying countenance,
But in this gentleman, Winifrid to my closet,
Fetch me the cordial,

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.l: What d'ye mean gentlewomen,
I do not feel any such dangerous sickness.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: What a hollow voice he has, o my misfortune
If he should die here, fetch me some strong waters.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: No no, I can walk for 'em myself if need be.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: He talks wildly:
I may suspect him, if you've so much strength
To walk, go home, call your physician,
And friends, dispose of your estate, and settle
Your peace for heaven I do beseech you sir.
My prayers shall beg a mercy on your soul:
For I have no encouragement to hope
Your glass hath many sands, farewell sir, cherish
Pare holy thoughts, that if your life soon end,
your better part may to you court ascend, come to my father. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: What's the meaning a this sick and dying, I feel no pain, I have heard of some died with conceit, if it should kill me, I were a precious coxcomb, was ever poor gentleman brought into such a foolish paradise prepared for a race, and mounting into th' saddle, I must go home and die, well, if I live I'll quit your cunning, and for the more certainty, my revenge may prosper, I won't say my prayers till it take effect. Enter tutor.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: This is the place where I must exercise my valour upon brains, I was never given to fight, but I'm engaged for such a prize as I would challenge all the noble sciences in my own defence.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: I cannot spy 'em, yet, pray heaven no
Disaster cross our project,

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: What thing's that walks about the door?

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: One practising I
Think, the postures of a fencer.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Things occur worthy consideration:

Were I best to speak before I strike him, or give him blows, and tell him reason afterwards. I do not like expostulations, they proclaim our anger, and give the enemy warning to defend himself, I'll strike him valiantly and in silence.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: What does he mutter?

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: What business stays him here, some treachery.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.l: Being resolved to strike before I speak.
'Tis worth my judgement, whether fist or sword
Shall first salute him, I'll be generous,
And give him first two or three wholesome buffets,
Which well laid on, may happily so maze him,
My weapon may be useless, for I fear
Should I begin with steel, her very face
Would force me make too deep incision,
And so there may be work for sessions,
I like not that as valiant as I am,
Killing is common.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Clare, they are in sight, down, down, o my ravished soul, what bliss is in this object?

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Ha they are coming, 'tis she and the old ruffian he has but a scurvy countenance, I ha' th'advantage in the first blow, and I should be very sorry, he should beat me in the conclusion.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Why does this fellow stay?

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.l: I must on, she has spied me through her mask,
I see her smile already, and command
A present battery.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Will this fellow prevent my office, he goes towards him with a quarrelling face, ha, I'll not engage myself, then 'tis so: withdraws

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Help, help. She runs in and presently slips out sencible dressed like her mistress.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Mistress stay, fear nothing, alas good gentlewoman, you black maggot death, I'd tread him into the kennel amongst his kindred.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.l: Hold, help, murder,

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: We shall have the whole street about's presently
Let's on our journey, who is this mole-catcher?
And ye had not been wi'me, I would have cut
Him into more pieces than a tailor's cushion,
Sir Nicholas you shall know on't too. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.l: They are gone together, pox a this toughness,
Has made an ass of me, next him do I hate the law
Most abominably, for if I might kill and not be hanged:
sp.p: For him 'twould never trouble me, shall I lose my reputation, so I'll venture another pounding, but I'll be revenged on him. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p:
My mistress is grown very thtisty of her voice a'the sudden, I have asked her 2. or three questions, and she answers me with holding out her hand, as the post at st. Albans that points the way to London, either she is
grown sullen, or the fright she was in late like a wolf that sees a man first, hath taken away her voice, — I'll make her speak to me — he stays, she puts him forward with her hand. — said you forsooth — we will not do, what a blessed comfort shall he enjoy if she continue speechless, the Persians did worship a god under the name of silence, and sure Christians may have an excuse for their idolatry, if they can find a woman whom nature hath posted into the world with a tongue, but no ability to make use of that miserable organ, what do you think 'tis o'clock ? two not stroke, ha? how now Mrs. treading a toside, this is your way to the exchange. She slips away.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: My way you saucy clown, take that,

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: You are bountiful, 'tis more than I looked for.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: What ha' you to say to me sirrah, cannot a gentlewoman

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Ha ah my brains melt, I am undone, I am undone, you succubus where is my mistress? Proserpine speak.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: That's he, your office.

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: We arrest you sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Me you toads?

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Away with him to prison, 'tis no slight action, at your perils sergeants — my fairest mistress.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Mistress — I'll honour this plot for the mirth' sake.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Sirrah Tadpoole what d'ye mean, I owe him not a penny by this flesh, he has a conspiracy upon me, I charge ye in the King's name unbind me.

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.l: We charge you i'th King's name obey us,

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: May you live to be arrested ath' pox, and die in a dungeon, nay inns a court gentleman, at next trimming shave your ears and noses off, and then duck you in their own boggards.

div.head: Scaena. i.
div.stage: Enter sir George, sir Nicholas, Mr. worthy.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: So, now we have got a licence, I would see who dares marry your daughter besides myself, is she come from the exchange yet?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Not yet sir. Enter a messenger.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: Your servant brains remembers his duty in this paper.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Letters!

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Letters, let me read 'em.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Your patience sir.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: I doubt all is not well, what if some misfortune should now befall your mistress, I hope you have armour of patience?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I and of proof too at home, as much as my hall can hold, the story of the prodigal can hardly be seen for't; I have pikes and guns, enough for me and my predecessors, a whole wardrobe of swords and bucklers, when you come home you shall see 'em.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: A conspiracy.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: O treason.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: My man brains is arrested by your tutor, a plot to take away my daughter, she is gone.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: I did prophesy too soon.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: My tutor read travel to me, and run away.
With my wench — a very peripatetic — what shall I do then, and some had arrested and clapped her up too — we should have known where to find her — d'ye hear, I did not mean to marry with a licence.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: How sir?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: No sir, I did mean to marry with your daughter am I a gull?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Have patience.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I will have no patience, I will have Violetta, why does not brains appear?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: His heels are not at liberty, he's in prison.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: In prison, why and he had been hanged, he might have brought us word.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: I'm rent with vexation, sirrah go you with me to the prison. Exit George and messenger.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: What will you do?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I'll geld my tutor.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: You were best find him first.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Nay I will find him, and find him again and I can light on him, let me alone, I'll take half a dozen wi'me and about it instantly. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: I wish thee well niece, but a better husband.
Who's yonder, 'tis master fowler, at an excellent opportunity. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: I do walk still, by all circumstance I am alive, not sick in any part but my head, which has only the pangs of invention, and is in travel of some precious revenge, for my worse than masculine affront, what if I report abroad she's dishonest, I cannot do 'em a worse turn than to say so: some of our gallants take a pride to belie poor gentlewomen a' that fashion, and think the discourse an honour to 'em; confidently boast the fruition of this or that lady, whose hand they never kissed with the glove off: and why may not I make it my revenge, to blur their fames a little for abusing me.

div.stage: Enter two friends at several doors.

sp.p: Well met friend, what? thou lookest sad.
You will excuse me, and bear a part, when I tell the cause.
What's the news?
Our friend master fowler's dead.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Fowler! Ha?
Mr. John Fowler.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: That's I, that's I, ha?
The same.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Dead, am I dead?

sp.l: It cannot be, I saw him but this morning
Lusty and pleasant, how died he?

sp.p: Suddenly.
Where?
At master worthies house.
Dead!
Too true sir.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: I would not believe myself sick, belike I am dead, 'tis more than I know yet.
He was a suitor to master worthies daughter.
Mistress Penelope, right.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: By all circumstance they mean me, these gentlemen know me too, how long is it since I departed? Some mistake —

sp.l: How poor a thing is life, that we cannot
Promise a minute's certainty, i'th height
And strength of youth, falling to dust again.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Ha, ha, gentlemen, what d'ye think a'the dead man?
'Tis the last office I can do him, now to wait on him to the earth.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Coxcombs d'ee not know me, I'm alive, d'ye not see me?

sp.l: He was a noble fellow, and deserves
A memory, if my brain have not lost
All his poetic juice, it shall go hard
But I'll squeeze out an elegy.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: For whom my furious poet, ha, not know me, do I walk invisible, or am I my own ghost, and you woe not see me, you shall feel me, you have a nimble pate, I may chance strike out some flash of wit — no —
Here comes another, save you master worthy.
Sir I heard ill news, master fowlers dead.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: He is indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Indeed you lie sir.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: I saw his eyes sealed up by death, and him
Rapt in his last sheet.

sp.p: Where's his body?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: At my sad house sir.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Is my body at your house?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: I did hope gentlemen, we should ha' found
My house his bridal chamber, not his coffin.
But heaven must be obeyed, my daughter loved him,
And ▪ much laments his loss.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Very good, than I am dead, am I not?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: You both were in the number of his friends,
I hope you'll add your presence to the rest, a'the funeral.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Whose funeral, you man of bedlam.
Cry mercy sir, pray keep your way.

sp.l: It is a duty which without invitement
We are both prompt to discharge.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Master worthy, gentlemen d'ye hear. Ex. man. Fow.is't possible, not know me, not see me, I am so thin, and airy, I ha' slipped out a'the world it seems, and did not know on't — if I be dead, what place am I in, where am I? This is not hell, sure I feel no torment, and there is too little company, no 'tis not hell — and I ha' not lived after the rate of going to heaven; yet beside, I met just now a usurer, that only deals upon ounces, and carries his scales at his girdle, with which he uses to weigh, not men's necessities, but the plate he is to lend money upon, can this fellow come to heaven? Here a poor fellow is put i'th stocks for being drunk, and the constable himself reeling home, charges others i'th King's name to aid him. There's a spruce captain, newly crept out of a gentleman usher, and shuffled into a buff jerkin with gold lace, that never saw service beyond Finsbury or the artillery garden, marches waving a desperate feather in his lady's beaver, while a poor soldier, bred up in the school of war all his life, yet never commenced any degree of commander, wants a piece of brass, to discharge a wheaten bullet to his? belly no — this is not heaven I know by the people that traffic in't, where am I then? Umh I'll to worthies before they bury me, and inform myself better what's become a me, if I find not myself there in a coffin, there's hope I may revive again, if I be dead, I am in a world very like the other, I will get me a female spirit to converse withal and kiss, and be merry, and imagine myself alive again. Exit.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Come follow me, and be valiant my masters.

sp.speaker: Whib.
sp.p: Remember yourself sir, this is your worship's footman, and for mine own part, though I be not cut

sp.l: Will be your honour, and the deed itself
Reward us in his benefit, he was ever wild

sp.p: Assured your ends are noble, we are happy in '.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Master fowler.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Is he come already?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Remove the hearse into this chamber
In your nobleness, I desire you will
Interpret fairly what I am to personate
And by the story you will find I have
Some cause of passion.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: This is the room I sickened in, and by report died in, umh I have heard of spirits walking with aerial bodies, and ha' been wondered at by others, but I must only wonder at myself, for if they be not mad, I'm come to my own burial, certain these clothes are substantial, I owe my tailor for 'em to this hour, if the devil be not my tailor, and hath furnished me with another suit very like it — this is no magical noise, essential gold and silver? What do I with it if I be dead? Here are no reckonings to be paid with it, no tavern bills, no midnight revels, with the costly tribe of amorous she sinners, now I cannot spend it, would the poor had it, by their prayers I might hope to get out of this new pitiful purgatory, or at least know which way I came in to't — here they are in mourning, what a devil do they mean to do with me — not too many tears lady, you will but spoil your eyes, and draw upon 'em the misery of spectacles, do not you know me neither?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: O master fowler.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Ha, out wi't, nay and the woman but acknowledge me alive, there's some hope a me.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: I loved thee living with a holy flame to purge the errors of thy wanton youth.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: I'm dead again.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: This made thy soul sue out so hasty a divorce.
And flee to airy dwellings, hath
Left us thy cold pale figure, which we have
Commission but to chamber up in
Melancholy dust, where thy own worms
Like the false servants of some great man shall
Devour thee first.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.l: I am worm's meat,

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: We must all die.

sp.speaker: Fow:
sp.p: Wooed some of you would do't quickly, that I might ha' company,

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: But wert thou now to live again with us
And that by miracle thy soul should with thy
Body have second marriage, I believe
Thou wouldst study to keep it a chaste temple, holy
Thoughts like fumes of sacred incense hovering
About this heart, than thou wouldst learn to be
Above thy frailties, and resist the flatteries of
Smooth-faced lust.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: This is my funeral sermon.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: The burden of which sin, my fears persuade me, both hastened and accompanied thy death.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: This sorrow is unfruitful.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I ha' done,
May this prayer profit him, would his soul were
As sure to gain heaven as his body's, here,

sp.p: We must hope the best, he was an inconstant young man ▪ frequenting of some companies, had corrupted his nature, and a little debauched him.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p:
In all this sermon I have heard little commendations of our dear brother departed, rich men do not go to th'pithole without compliment of Christian burial, it seems if I had lived to ha' made a will, and bequeathed so much legacy as would purchase some preacher a neat cassock, I should ha' died in as good estate and assurance for my soul as the best gentleman i'th parish, had my monument in a conspicuous place of the church, where I should ha' been cut in a form of prayer, as if I had been called
away at my devotion, and so for haste to be in heaven, went thither with my book and spectacles — d'ye hear lady and gentlemen, is it your pleasure to see me, though not know me? and to inform a walking business when this so much lamented brother of yours departed out of this world, in his life I had some relation to him, what disease died he of prey? who is his heir yet at common law, for he was warm in the possession of lands, thank his kind father, who having been in a consumption sixteen years, one day above all the rest having nothing else to do, died, that the young man might be a landlord, according to the custom of his ancestors:
I doubt the project.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: You should be his heir or executor at least by your dry eyes, sir I commend thee, what a miserable folly 'tis to weep for one that's dead, and has no sense of our lamentation, wherefore were blacks invented? to save our eyes their tedious distillations, 'tis enough to be sad in our habits, they have cause to weep that have no mourning cloth, 'tis a sign they get little by the dead, and that's the greatest sorrow now adays, you loved him lady, to say truth you had little cause, a wild young man ▪ yet and he were alive again, as that's in vain to wish you know, he may perchance be more sensible, and reward you with better service, so you would not proclaim his weakness, — faith speak well a'th dead hereafter and bury all his faults with him, will ye, what are these all the guests? ha? what papers? some elegy or epitaph? who subscribes? o this is your poetry.

lg.l: How he died some do suppose
How he sinned the parish knows,
Whether he's gone to heaven or hell,
Ask not me I cannot tell.

sp.p: Very well, would the gentleman your friend were alive to give you thanks for 'em.
sp.l: What have we more?

lg.l: Underneath, the fair not wise,
Too self loved Narcissus lies,
Yet his sad destruction came
From no fountain but a flame,
Than youth quench your hot desires,
Purge your thoughts with chaster fires,
Lest with him it be too late,
And death triumph in your fate
Hither all you virgins come,
Strew your tears upon this tomb.
Perhaps a timely weeping may
So dispose his scorched clay,
That a chaste and snowy flower
May reward your gentle shower.

sp.p: Very well done upon so dead a subject, by the virgin that's in't, you should owe this parcel of poetry lady.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: A woman's muse sir,

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: O now you can answer me, am I dead still?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Yes:

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Then you talk to a dead man.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Where am I dead?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Here, everywhere .
You're dead to virtue, to all noble thoughts,
And till the proof of your conversion
To piety win my faith, you are to me
Without all life, and charity to myself,
Bids me endeavour with this ceremony
To give you burial if hereafter I
Let in my memory to my thoughts, or see you.
You shall but represent his ghost or shadow
Which never shall have power to fright my innocence.
Or make my cheek look pale, my ends are compassed,
And here in sight of heaven.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.l: Stay,
Thou'rt a noble girl, and dost deserve
To marry with an emperor, remove
this sad thing from us, you do know me gentlemen
Witness my death to vanity, quitting all
Unchaste desires, revive me in thy thoughts,
And I will love as thou hast taught me nobly
And like a husband, by this kiss the seal
That I do shake my wanton slumber off,
And wake to virtue.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Meet it daughter.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Now you begin to live:

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: I will grow old i'th study of my honour, this last conflict hath quite o'ercome me, make me happy in the style of your son.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: My blessings multiply.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: We congratulate this event.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: See my brother. Enter sir George ▪ brains.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Let not your rage be so high sir, I ha' more cause to be mad,

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Thou?

sp.speaker: Bra:
sp.p: I.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: I have lost my daughter.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: But I have lost my credit, that had nothing else to live. I was more proud of that then you could be of twenty daughters,

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Have you found 'em?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Not, not, and yet this old ruffian will not let me vex for it, he says the greatest loss is his.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p:
And I'll maintain it, 'twas my boast that I was never cozened in my life, have I betrayed so many plots, discovered letters, deciphered characters, stripped knavery to the skin, and laid open the very soul of conspiracy, deserved for my cunning to be called brains both town and country over, and now to forfeit 'em, to see 'em drenched in a muddy stratagem, cheated by a woman, and a pedantical lousy woodmonger, 'tis abominable; patience I abhor thee, I desire him that bids me go hang myself, which is the way to surgeons' hall I'll beg to ha' my skull cut, I have a suspicion my brains are filched, and my head has been late stuffed with woodcock's
feathers.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Be not mad.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: I will in spite of any man here, who shall hinder me if I have a mind to't.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Your happiness removes my affliction, ha!

sp.speaker: Vvhib:
sp.p: Where is sir Nicholas? we have brought the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Are you there — this was the champion that justled me, shall I fetch a dog-whip, or let me cut him up he will make excellent meat for the devil's trencher, I'll carve him sirrah.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Forbear, where is my daughter? villain confess.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Alas sir, I was waiting upon her home, sir Nicholas met me, and took her from me.

sp.speaker: Geo. Wor.
sp.p: Sir Nicholas!

sp.speaker: Vvhib.
sp.p: Yes sir Nicholas, hath mistress Violetta, I am a witness.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Why did he justle me, there began the treachery, ask him that?

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: I pray y' sir let it be forgotten, I ha' been kicked for't.

div.stage: Enter at one door Mr., Aymwell, Violetta, Manly, Clare, at the other, sir Nicholas and sensible.

sp.speaker: Whib.
sp.p: Here she is, no there she is.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Sir Nicholas:

sp.speaker: Wor:
sp.l: I am amazed:

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Stay which is my wife?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Here's my daughter.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Mistress!

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Fine juggling. Francke whence comest?

sp.speaker: Aym:
sp.l: From the priest, if you have any joy for me,
We are married.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Are there not two sir nicholases, pray what d'ye call this gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Aymw.
sp.p: Her name's Violetta.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Father your pardon.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p:
This is fine i'faith, well may a woman mistake her
husband, when a man that is the wiser vessel cannot know his own wife.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Married to Aymwell!

sp.speaker: Man. Cla.
sp.p: We are witnesses.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: A good jest i'faith, hark you, were you ever catechised? What is your name forsooth?

sp.speaker: Sens.
sp.p: Faith sir guess.

sp.speaker: Aymw.
sp.p: All passion will be fruitless but of joy.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: Sensible? Came I from Croyden for a chambermaid?
D'ye hear everybody I ha' married sensible!

sp.speaker: Man. Cla.
sp.p: We are witnesses of that too.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: No no, this is my wife.

sp.speaker: Aymw.
sp.p: Touch her not with a rude hand.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Why, I know she meant to be my wife, and only I ha' married her, as folks go to law, by attorney, she is but her deputy, for the more state I married her by proxy.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Do not deceive yourself sir, though princes depute men to marry their wives, women do not use to be ciphers, she is your wife in law, let me counsel you sir to prevent laughter, somebody hath been cozened, I name nobody , since it was your fortune to marry this wench, which cannot now be undone, seem not to be sorry for't, they do purpose to jeer you out of your skin else.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Say'st thou so?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Be confident and laugh at them first, that they are so simple to think that you are gulled, commend your choice, and say 'twas a trick of yours to deceive their expectation.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Come hither madam Treedle, gentlemen, you think now, I have but an ill match on't, and that as they say I am cheated, do not believe it — a lady is a lady, a bargain is a bargain, and I'm a knight and no gentleman, so much for that — I grant I married her, in her mistress's name, and though (As great men, that use to choose wives for their favourites or servants, when they have done with 'em) I could put her off to my footman or my tutor here, I won't, I will maintain her my wife and publish her, d'ye see, publish her to any man that shall laugh at it, my own ladybird, and madam Treedle.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: You are happy sir, in being deceived, he is a noble gentleman.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Sir Nicholas has released her,
Let your consent be free then.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: You have won it
Be my loved children, and I wish a joy
Flow in all bosoms. Brains we are reconciled.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Tutor we pardon.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: You may sir, he was my engine, now,
What says my factious servant, nay, we're friends,
The greatest politician may be
Deceived sometimes, wit without brains ye see.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: And brains without wit too.

sp.speaker: Fowl.
sp.p: Frank thou art married, and sir Nicholas has made a lady, I ha' lived loose a great while, and do purpose to be made fast to this gentlewoman.
sp.l: To whose act I owe my true conversion.
When all things have their trial, you shall find.
Nothing is constant but a virtuous mind. Exeunt.

div.p: This play, called the witty fair one, as it was acted on the stage, may be printed, this 14. of January. 1632.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
